Award.AbstractNarration:
Most insect species on earth carry specific bacteria that are passed from infected females to their offspring. Many of these bacteria are beneficial to their hosts in such ways as conferring resistance to pathogens. Because insects are important members of larger ecological communities, the bacteria they carry may affect the structure and dynamics of these communities. The proposed research will examine several community-level effects of specific bacteria that infect specific mushroom-feeding flies. The bacteria living inside flies confer resistance to the sterilizing effects of a parasitic nematode worm and thus increase the fitness of parasitized flies. In addition, the bacteria dramatically affect the population dynamics of these parasitic nematodes: nematode parasitism increases rapidly in fly populations that lack bacteria, but the nematodes quickly go extinct in bacteria-infected populations. This project will investigate three questions: 1) How do bacteria affect the relative abundance of various species of competing flies, both in the presence and absence of nematode parasitism? 2) How does the presence of bacteria in one fly species affect the rate of nematode parasitism in other fly species? 3) Under what conditions can bacteria spread to new fly species?

This research has potential broader impacts in the areas of public health and agriculture. Filarial nematodes cause onchocerciasis (River Blindness) and lymphatic filariasis in humans, with about 160 million people currently infected worldwide. These nematodes are carried from one person to another by insect vectors. If specific bacteria adversely affect nematodes within insect vectors, it might be possible to introduce the bacteria into populations of these insects and thus reduce the transmission, prevalence, and severity of certain diseases. As a potential agricultural application, bacteria or genes derived from them could be introduced to crop plants to provide resistance to root-knot nematodes, which annually cause over $120 billion in agricultural damage around the world. The proposed work includes several projects suited to undergraduate research. The PI will work with the Kearns Center at the University of Rochester to recruit low-income, first-generation, and underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insects are by far the most diverse group of animals on earth, and a majority of insect species have been found to carry one or more species of heritable endosymbiotic bacteria. These are bacteria that are transmitted solely from infected mothers through the eggs to their offspring, with essentially no infectious transmission from infected to uninfected individuals. Despite their widespread occurrence, the function of these bacteria is known in relatively few cases.

We have discovered that a species of fruit fly, Drosophila neotestacea, carries a heritable bacterium of the genus Spiroplasma. We have found that the infection frequency of Spiroplasma has increased from 10%-15% in the 1980s to about 70% today, a level at which it has remain stabilized for the past 6 years. Furthermore, we have found that the Spiroplasma infection is spreading rapidly from east to west across North America. The rapid spread of Spiroplasma is due to the fact that it confers resistance to the sterilizing effects of a common roundworm (nematode) parasite.

We have recently found that the frequency of nematode parasitism in D. neotestacea has declined by over 50% – from 23% in the 1980s to 10% today – following the spread of Spiroplasma. This is because Spiroplasma greatly reduces the reproductive output of nematodes that occur within Spiroplasma-infected flies. Thus, the spread of Spiroplasma has both reduced the frequency of nematode infection in wild populations of Drosophila and reduced the severity of infection within those flies that do get infected.

Several other species of Drosophila also carry their own unique strains of Spiroplasma. We have transferred multiple strains of Spiroplasma into D. neotestacea and found that it is only the strain that naturally occurs in this species that has anti-nematode properties. Consequently, we undertook an initial study of the comparative genomics of these Spiroplasma strains in an attempt to find genes or sets of genes that occur uniquely in the D. neotestacea strain of Spiroplasma. Our results indicate that there are several such genes, and that they all appear to be carried on a plasmid, which is a small extra-chromosomal segment of DNA. Plasmids have the capacity to jump intact from one bacterial species to another, thus conferring entirely new traits on them, such as antibiotic resistance.

The nematodes that parasitize Drosophila are closely related to plant-parasitic nematodes, which annually cause over $150 billion damage worldwide. Virtually all crop plants are susceptible to one of more species of plant-parasitic nematodes. These parasites are particularly devastating in developing countries. Our finding of a putative plasmid carrying genes that probably encode anti-nematode genes raises the possibility of using these genes to genetically modify crop plants to render them resistant to plant-parasitic nematodes. Such engineered crops could be especially beneficial in Africa, where small-holder farmers struggle economically to make ends meet.
